Okay. Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks very much for taking part in the conference call for BTU. With us today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Boyce; Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Mike Crews; and President and Chief Commercial Officer, Rick Navarre.
Forward-looking statements should be considered along with the risk factors that we note at the end of our release, as well as the MD&A section of our filed documents. We also refer you to peabodyenergy.com for additional information.
And with, that I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we entered 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our Mining Operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14% both the l
componenttext:
Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we entered 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our Mining Operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14% both the line on cost and expanded margins across the platform. Our cash flow generation was substantial and our balance sheet is stronger than ever. we raised our dividend and we're executing on a number of growth projects all over the world. In short, Peabody is a long-runway of growth and financial opportunities ahead. I'll begin with a review of our income statement and operational highlights.
Our 2010 sales volume totaled 246 million tons slightly above last year as higher Western U.S. and Australian volumes more than offset lower Trading and Brokerage activity. Revenues reached a record $6.9 billion on a The combination of improved realized prices and higher volumes in Australia and the Western U.S. Australia was a key driver with revenues $842 million above last year.
Those higher prices, combined with lower U.S. costs showed a consolidated EBITDA of $1.82 billion, 41% above the prior year.
Moving on to taxes. Our effective tax rate, excluding currency remeasurement was 23% for the full year. Taxes for the fourth quarter were below previous quarters of 2010 due to lower-than-expected contributions from Australia which have a higher effective tax rate. Going forward, we anticipate our full year effective tax rate will be up to 25% higher or 25% depending on the mix of earnings.
Income from continuing operations rose to $805.1 million. Excluding the impact of $48 million of non-cash currency measurement, our adjusted income from continuing operations totaled $853 million with adjusted diluted EPS of $3.05 both significantly above prior-year levels.
Let me take you through the EBITDA components in more detail, beginning with Australia which more than doubled its contribution. Our volumes in Australia  reached 27 million tons which was nearly 5 million tons higher than last year, reflecting both the investments we've made in the platform and the rising demand in the Pacific.
Breaking down Australia sales volumes, we sold 9.8 million tons of met coal in 2010 at an average price of $164 per metric ton which was approximately 20% higher than last year. On the thermal side, we sold 11 million tons of seaborne thermal product the throughout the year, our largest such volumes to date and at a higher average price of $78 per metric ton.
Let me take a moment to discuss the Australia rains that have been occurring most notably since December. For the industry, one of the hardest hit areas has been the mines and rail system serving the port which we don't ship through. For Peabody, we've been impacted by flooding to varying degrees at our service mines and have also seen reduced rail and port performance.
The combination of lower-than-expected fourth quarter volumes along with repair recovery expenses reduced EBITDA approximately $85 million or $0.22 per share after tax. First quarter were also be impacted by lower volumes as we ramped back up to normal levels.
In 2010, our full year cost to Australia averaged $58 per ton in line with our expectations despite the rain effects. All told, our Australia gross margin rose to 38% for the year versus 26% in 2009.
Turning now to the U.S. Our operations ran very well and related EBITDA rose 14% to $1.1 billion. In the Midwest, our margins per ton increased 22% to nearly $11 per ton as higher contracted prices more than offset a modest increase in cost from slightly lower volumes. And in the West, our margins increased 11% on higher average revenues and costs that were more than 2% below 2009 levels.
All in, our consolidated Mining Operations turned in record results. We also generated $101 million of EBITDA from our Trading and Brokerage and Resource Management businesses. 
You'll know our fourth quarter Trading results were lower than average largely to three factors. First, we had lower international brokerage earnings relative to higher 2009 performance. We also had some shipment deferrals due to Australia weather, several of which have been shipped or are expected to ship this quarter. And finally, the freight position that supports our future expert volumes had unfavorable mark-to-market movements. Whether depressed of freight markets causing them to decline in the fourth quarter versus an increase last year. Like the deferrals these are temporary and at the latest, will reverse when the shipments occur.
Going forward, we continue to target quarterly EBITDA from this segment at a two-year quarterly average of approximately 31%.
Turning to the balance sheet. Our strong performance resulted in cash flows from operation of $1.1 billion, which drove our cash balance to $1.3 billion. Our rise in cash flow allowed us to increase our dividend by more than 20% even as we fun a number of growth projects.
The capital program for 2011 is rising to accommodate our organic growth projects. Of this year's $900 million to $950 million of planned spending, $500 million to $550 million is earmarked for growth and extension projects in Australia and the U.S. 2011 sustaining capital is estimated to average approximately $1.80 per produced ton on continued modernization of our equipment fleet.
Before I close, I'd like to cover our outlook. For the first quarter, we're expecting lower sales volumes and higher average costs due to the rains in Australia. We also have a long wall moved plan for Colorado and one in Australia. As a result, first quarter EBITDA is targeted in the range of $325 million to $425 million with adjusted earnings per share of $0.45 to $0.65.
For the full year, our U.S. volumes are targeted to be 195 million to 205 million tons with stable average margins across the platform leading to U.S. EBITDA within 5% of 2010.
Australia sales are targeted to be 28 million to 30 million tons compared with 27 million tons in 2010. And with Trading and Brokerage, our total company 2011 sales are likely to be in the 245 million to 265 million-ton range. Given the rapid market developments and their potential for meaningful impact, we look forward to providing you outlook updates throughout the year.
And so with that review, a very strong 2010 results and our outlook, I'll now turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the are
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the areas such as global safety and revenues and had major increases in our EBITDA, operating profit and income. We started up the Bear Run Mine in the Midwest and shipped our first coal through the NCIG terminal in New Castle. We expanded El Segundo in New Mexico and sold record volumes from our premium PRB for shell mine and we move forward our project pipeline in Australia and various JVs in China, Mongolia and Indonesia.
We've began 2011 solidly in the first phase of a long-term coal supercycle. [Audio Gap] Continuation of the two speed global engine with China, India and emerging Asia growing at 8% to 10% and Europe and the U.S. still in lower gear. In the Pacific Sewall market coal demand grew nearly 20% in 2010 to a record 700 million tons. China continued as the world's fastest-growing coal importer and shattered its prior-year net import record with 147 million tons. India continue to expand coal imports and Japan and Korea also bounced back from earlier recession.
This year, we expect further robust growth in global seaborne coal demand, which may exceed 1 billion metric tons for the first time ever, look for China and India to again lead the growth. And at the same time, coal supplies are being challenged by events in most major exporting nations. The Southern Hemisphere is home to more than 3/4 of the world's seaborne coal supplies. La Nina has brought heavy rains to Australia, Indonesia, South Africa and South America as well has been hampered in the Eastern U.S. and Western Canada. So rising demand and strain supplies are translating into sharp sharper price increases. Just since October, the spot met coal price is up well over 50% and the new castle thermal has risen more than 35%. This bodes extremely well as we approach upcoming settlements for quarterly met in annual thermal contracts. And our leverage to these markets is outstanding. Essentially all of Peabody's met coal beyond this quarter is open to pricing and half of our thermal export coals available to price for 2011 was 85% open for 2012.
Now Mike reviewed the effects of the Australia  flooding on our results. I'd like to the give you a brief update where we stand today. Our Cleveland mines continue to work through force majeurs with customers and recover from the storms. Today, the major questions are: What will the normal rainy season which urges beginning bring to us?
Whether our coal shippers will have coal available when we have coal products ready to ship, and for our quick operation, when will the rail line to the fork be restored. We received multiple reports each day from our Australia team, which has been working tirelessly through personal and professional challenges. But their goal is to minimize the impacts of flooding and to recover as quickly as possible. Case in point. We just sold a spot of semi-hard coking coal to a major customer for prices that are significantly above those settled for the first quarter.
So as we quickly work through these short-term weather-related issues, we're keenly focused on capturing the significant upside potential resulting from the 7 million to 8 million tons of metallurgical coal and the 6 million to 7 million tons of thermal coal that we have yet to price for 2011.
Now let's look at the U.S. markets. Last year, a low natural gas price still wasn't enough to derail a 5.5% increase in coal fueled generation. Coal regain market share in 2010 and powered nearly 2/3 of incremental power outlet. Exports increased, led by met coal in the East and PRB in the West. And I'd note that U.S. coal demand has largely tracked industrial output, which were declining 9% in 2009 bounced back 6% in 2010. We see muted improvement in 2011 with manufacturing growth, natural gas prices and export volumes holding the keys to any further increases.
On the supply side, we expect continued market share gains from the Illinois Basin and Powder River Basin. And we continue to shape our contract book to the match the curve of the U.S. rebound, with 2012 and beyond continuing to look much brighter.
Now embedded in this near-term market movements are elements of much longer trends. I've noted that I believe we're in the early stages of a long-term supercycle for coal. We see evidence of these around us today. Coal has been the world's fastest-growing fuel and i.e. projects that growth in coal generation will be more than double that of any other fuel through 2020. And by 2020, global generation capacity in steel production are both expected to grow some 50%. China's electricity and industrial production will again grow at low-teen rates and China's new power plants and steel mills will require several hundred million tons of added coal each year.
India is rapidly increasing coal imports and developed economies are starting to see growth in their manufacturing base. So what's important to investors goes beyond whether met coal is $375 per ton. The key is that global demand for coal is strongly and steadily rising and supplies stretched such that disruptions become quickly apparent.
So where does this lead Peabody? We are ideally position for the supercycle. Peabody benefits from rising volumes within a support of price backdrop. A powerful earnings combination that should sustain our growth for years to come. In 2011, Peabody will use its position in the fastest-growing markets to target the following key areas. We will capture value from upward price, movements, within our significant open position. We will advance expansion of six major Australian metallurgical and thermal export mines and work to recapture value lost from the recent flooding.
We will advanced emerging growth projects and commercial transactions in China, Mongolia, Indonesia and India. And we will continue to leverage Peabody's leadership in the three primary growth avenues for the U.S., the Powder River Basin, Illinois Basin and U.S. exports.
And we will maintain our intensity for excellence in our core areas of safety, operations, portfolio management, Trading and Brokerage and social responsibility. I want to thank all Peabody employees for their continued efforts. They are the key to our success. And we believe Peabody offers all of you a pure play investment for the global reach, access to the very best markets and growth rate well above our peers.
So with that overview, we'll now be happy to answer any questions you may have.

componenttext: Well, I think it's a good question to comparison is to be made between 2008 and 2010 or '11 where we sit today in Australia. There's no question Mike although the flooding and the impacts in Australia  are much greater today than they were in the 2008. They're more widespread, they cover a larger area. When you remember back in 2008 there was a central core in Queensland along that Black Water line in the gladstone that was hardest hit. This year, there were impact across the entire Queensland platform and right at the end of 2010, some impacts in New South Wales. When you look at 2010, you're probably 8 million to 10 million-ton impact out of Australia. This year we're looking at 15 million to 20 million tons of impact, so almost twice. Plus you've got South Africa, you've got Colombia, all and in Indonesia all having concurrent impacts. So when you look at the global perspective, this year's event is much more significant. And in some cases, will take a longer period of time to recover depending on the reason that we are talking about.

componenttext: Without going into specifics mine by mine, on our force majeure obviously we've got to have a lot of discussions with our customers, let me give a sense as to where we're at operationally today and what we see as some of the recovery times. When I just start from the south let's say that New South Wales is essentially back on track and operating normally from any impacts that they might have in the fourth quarter. As we move up into Queensland it's a couple of different stories. As I mentioned earlier, the most significant impacts and the most catastrophic impacts were along that Blackwater Gladstone quarter which we do not have any operations in that area. As you go through the Goonyella DBCT Port Corridor, which affects our northern basin operations, and you look at our surface operations, our Burton operations, Eagle Field and the Millennium, all have significant rainfall. Millennium is essentially up and running at capacity although we've got some lower seeings that we have still yet to pump the pits down to be able to access for blending purposes. Our Burton operation, we still have significant pumping to do. You might recall, we've got multiple pits at that operation and we are beginning and we are producing out of some of those pits but we don't have access to 100% of them yet. It will take us a bit of time to pump those down. Eagle Field is essentially back up and running as an  a junk to our North Goonyella operations. In terms of North Goonyella we've had some access issues which will result fairly quickly and we also had a some geologic issues that we work through at the end of the year. But it is essentially up and running at full production as we speak today. So as you move south to our Wilke Creek operations, it's probably where we've had our biggest impact. We've just recently, within this week, been able to get full access to the site again and our back up limited production and we will be building that production based over the course of the next week. But longer-term, the rail line from Wilke Creek to the port of Brisbane was washed out in the significant flooding that they have in Brisbane which work we are all aware of. And we're still talking to Queensland rail as to what they think the repair estimates and time frame might be. But logically, that will probably be a month or two before we can see any clarity as to when that will be up and running. Hopefully it won't not be longer than within the quarter.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now
componenttext: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now at some point in time, in the future, we're going to obviously see a recovery in terms of the production base. But that the meantime, demand continues to grow, so the gap that we've opened up I think there's a significant portion of that gap that will permanent, albeit when things do normalize will see some of the top end come down a bit. But we don't see that occurring in the very short period of time.

componenttext: Let me address that. Peabody continues with serious efforts to secure a long-term facility to ship what we told you before, 20 million to 25 million tons of coal to the Asian markets. We're evaluating the options with partners. We a lot of this is we are confidentially agreements. What I could tell is that our goal is to get a low-cost option that could be a game changer for the market. And when we look at the options, we want a deepwater facility because to ship PRB coal, we believe we have to use Capesize vessels that improves your economics by $5 to $6 in metric ton over Panamax vessels that are being used in some of the other facilities that were available to look at. It has to have affordable rail opportunities and rail rates where as we evaluate some of the further north opportunities such as, it's a $10 to $15 disadvantage to some of the options that other options that we look at. So we try to find the right option that has long-term competitive advantages that can ship meaningful quantities of PRB coal and it has a one-line haul as opposed to a two or three line rail haul to get to the port. So we hope to be able to give you information in the next quarter on this but continues to progress very rapidly a lot of work is going on and we don't want to announce anything prematurely.

componenttext: Sure. Well, I'm not really up to speed on the specifics and what happened back in West Virginia with that one permit that you referenced. Suffice it to say that all of the permitting is under more scrutiny here in the U.S. While we have built into all of our planning processes is a longer time frame for permitting, which incorporates earlier acquisition of land resources so that the permits can be applied for at an earlier time frame, longer window for both the state and federal permits to be received. componenttext: Well, if you go back to our discussions last quarter and then if you go back to the comments earlier about the gap that we have today, I think it was always our view that the met coal supply was much tighter than where met coal demand was going to be. That was even before all of the Australian rains and all the other production issues across the globe. So that said, that we had the dynamics for upward pressure on price across the globe. So layer on top of that, the production has been lost, we don't have overcapacity in the met coal circuit. We've never thought that there as it existed, which says that for that gap to be closed, it might get tampered when we get back up to full production. But in our view, it's not going to get closed. We're going to have an even tighter supply situation going forward. You know 42%, 40-plus percent of all met coal supply is currently operating under force majeure which gives you kind of a sense as to the significance of the issues.

componenttext: Well, on the thermal sights, it's a different situation. So we see with what's happened in Colombia, South Africa and Indonesia for the La Niña effects which is almost all predominantly thermal coal tightness in the thermal market as well. And significant run up in thermal pricing.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we entered 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our mining operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14%, held the
componenttext:
Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we entered 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our mining operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14%, held the line on cost and expanded margins across the platform. Our cash flow generation was substantial, and our balance sheet is stronger than ever. We raised our dividend, and we're executing on a number of growth projects all over the world. In short, Peabody has a long runway of growth and financial opportunities ahead. I'll begin with the review of our income statement and operational highlights.
Our 2010 sales volume totaled 246 million tons, slightly above last year as higher Western U.S. and Australian volumes more than offset lower Trading and Brokerage activity. Revenues reached a record $6.9 billion on a combination of improved realized prices and higher volumes in Australia and the Western U.S. Australia was a key driver with revenues $842 million above last year. Those higher prices, combined with lower U.S. costs, drove consolidated EBITDA to $1.82 billion, 41% above the prior year.
Moving on to taxes. Our effective tax rate, excluding currency remeasurement was 23% for the full year. Taxes for the fourth quarter were below previous quarters of 2010 due to lower-than-expected contributions from Australia, which have a higher effective tax rate. Going forward, we anticipate our full year effective tax rate will be up to 25% higher or 25% depending on the mix of earnings.
Income from continuing operations rose to $805.1 million. Excluding the impact of $48 million of non-cash currency remeasurement, our adjusted income from continuing operations totaled $853 million with adjusted diluted EPS of $3.05, both significantly above prior year levels.
Let me take you through the EBITDA components in more detail, beginning with Australia which more than doubled its contribution. Our volumes in Australia  reached 27 million tons, which was nearly 5 million tons higher than last year, reflecting both the investments we've made in the platform and the rising demand in the Pacific.
Breaking down Australia sales volumes, we sold 9.8 million tons of met coal in 2010 at an average price of $164 per metric ton, which was approximately 20% higher than last year. On the thermal side, we sold 11 million tons of seaborne thermal product throughout the year, our largest such volumes to date and at a higher average price of $78 per metric ton.
Let me take a moment to discuss the Australia rains that have been occurring most notably since December. For the industry, one of the hardest hit areas has been the mines and rail system serving the Gladstone port, which we don't ship through. For Peabody, we've been impacted by flooding to varying degrees at our service mines and have also seen reduced rail and port performance.
The combination of lower-than-expected fourth quarter volumes, along with repair recovery expenses, reduced EBITDA approximately $85 million or $0.22 per share after tax. The first quarter will also be impacted by lower volumes as we ramp back up to normal levels.
In 2010, our full year cost in Australia averaged $58 per ton in line with our expectations despite the rain effects. All told, our Australia gross margin rose to 38% for the year versus 26% in 2009.
Turning now to the U.S. Our operations ran very well, and related EBITDA rose 14% to $1.1 billion. In the Midwest, our margins per ton increased 22% to nearly $11 per ton as higher contracted prices more than offset a modest increase in cost from slightly lower volumes. And in the West, our margins increased 11% on higher average revenues and costs that were more than 2% below 2009 levels.
All in, our consolidated Mining Operations turned in record results. We also generated $101 million of EBITDA from our Trading and Brokerage and Resource Management businesses. You'll know that our fourth quarter Trading results were lower than average largely due to three factors. First, we had lower international brokerage earnings relative to higher 2009 performance. We also had some shipment deferrals due to Australia weather, several of which had since shipped or are expected to ship this quarter. 
And finally, the freight position that supports our future expert volumes had unfavorable mark-to-market movements. Weather depressed the freight markets, causing them to decline in the fourth quarter versus an increase last year. Like the deferrals, these are temporary and at the latest, will reverse when the shipments occur.
Going forward, we continue to target quarterly EBITDA from this segment at a two-year quarterly average of approximately $30 million. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Our strong performance resulted in cash flows from operation of $1.1 billion, which drove our cash balance to $1.3 billion. Our rise in cash flow allowed us to increase our dividend by more than 20% even as we fund a number of growth projects.
The capital program for 2011 is rising to accommodate our organic growth projects. Of this year's $900 million to $950 million of planned spending, $500 million to $550 million is earmarked for growth in extension projects in Australia and the U.S. 2011 sustaining capital is estimated to average approximately $1.80 per produced ton on continued modernization of our equipment fleet.
Before I close, I'd like to cover our outlook. For the first quarter, we're expecting lower sales volumes and higher average costs due to the rains in Australia. We also have a longwall move planned for Colorado and one in Australia. As a result, first quarter EBITDA is targeted in the range of $325 million to $425 million with adjusted earnings per share of $0.45 to $0.65.
For the full year, our U.S. volumes are targeted to be 195 million to 205 million tons, with stable average margins across the platform, leading to U.S. EBITDA within 5% of 2010. Australia sales are targeted to be 28 million to 30 million tons compared with 27 million tons in 2010. And with Trading and Brokerage, our total company 2011 sales are likely to be in the 245 million to 265 million-ton range. Given the rapid market developments and their potential for meaningful impact, we look forward to providing you outlook updates throughout the year.
And so with that review, a very strong 2010 results and our outlook, I'll now turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the are
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the areas such as global safety and revenues and had major increases in our EBITDA, operating profit and income. We started up the Bear Run Mine in the Midwest and shipped our first coal through the NCIG terminal in Newcastle. We expanded El Segundo in New Mexico and sold record volumes from our premium PRB North Antelope Rochelle Mine, and we moved forward our project pipeline in Australia and various JVs in China, Mongolia and Indonesia.
We began 2011 solidly in the first phase of a long-term coal supercycle. And Peabody has growth projects advancing in Australia, Asia and in the U.S. I'd like to review the key markets for our products as well as our key focus areas for 2011. 
This year, we see a continuation of the two-speed global economic engine with China, India and emerging Asia growing at 8% to 10%, and Europe and the U.S. still in lower gear. In the Pacific seaborne market, coal demand grew nearly 20% in 2010 to a record 700 million tons. China continued as the world's fastest-growing coal importer and shattered its prior year net import record with 147 million tons. India continue to expand the coal imports, and Japan and Korea also bounced back from earlier recession.
This year, we expect further robust growth in global seaborne coal demand, which may exceed 1 billion metric tons for the first time ever, look for China and India to again lead the growth, and at the same time coal supplies are being challenged by events in most major exporting nations. 
The Southern Hemisphere is home to more than 3/4 of the world's seaborne coal supplies. La Nina has brought heavy rains to Australia, Indonesia, South Africa and South America, as well exports have been hampered in the Eastern U.S. and Western Canada. So rising demand and strained supplies are translating into sharp price increases. Just since October, the spot met coal price is up well over 50%, and the Newcastle thermal has risen more than 35%. 
This bodes extremely well as we approach upcoming settlements for quarterly met in annual thermal contracts. And our leverage to these markets is outstanding. Essentially all of Peabody's met coal beyond this quarter is open to pricing and half of our thermal export coal is available to price for 2011, with 85% open for 2012.
Now Mike reviewed the effects of the Australia  flooding on our results. I'd like to the give you a brief update where we stand today. Our Cleveland mines continue to work through force majeures with customers and recover from the storms. Today, the major questions are what will the normal rainy season, which were just beginning, bring to us? Whether our coal shippers will have coal available when we have coal product ready to ship? And for our Wilkie Creek operation, when will the rail line to the Brisbane Port be restored? 
We receive multiple reports each day from our Australia team, which has been working tirelessly through personal and professional challenges. But their goal is to minimize the impacts of flooding and to recover as quickly as possible. A case in point, we just sold a spot Panamax of semi-hard coking coal to a major customer for prices that are significantly above those settled for the first quarter.
So as we quickly work through these short-term weather-related issues, we're keenly focused on capturing the significant upside potential resulting from the 7 million to 8 million tons of metallurgical coal and the 6 million to 7 million tons of thermal coal that we have yet to price for 2011.
Now let's look at the U.S. markets. Last year, a low natural gas price still wasn't enough to derail a 5.5% increase in coal-fueled generation. Coal regained market share in 2010 and powered nearly 2/3 of incremental power outlet. Exports increased, led by met coal in the East and PRB in the West. And I'd note that U.S. coal demand has largely tracked industrial output, which while declining 9% in 2009, bounced back 6% in 2010. We see muted improvement in 2011 with manufacturing growth, natural gas prices and export volumes holding the keys to any further increases.
On the supply side, we expect continued market share gains from the Illinois Basin and Powder River Basin. And we continue to shape our contract book to the match the curve of the U.S. rebound, with 2012 and beyond continuing to look much brighter.
Now embedded in these near-term market movements are elements of much longer trends. I've noted that I believe we're in the early stages of a long-term supercycle for coal. We see evidence of these around us today. Coal has been the world's fastest-growing fuel, and EIA [Energy Information Administration]
Projects that growth in coal generation will be more than double that of any other fuel through 2020. And by 2020, global generation capacity in steel production are both expected to grow some 50%. China's electricity and industrial production will again grow at low-teen rates, and China's new power plants and steel mills will require several hundred million tons of added coal each year. 
India is rapidly increasing coal imports and developed economies are starting to see growth in their manufacturing base. So what's important to investors goes beyond whether met coal is $375 per ton. The key is that global demand for coal is strongly and steadily rising, and supply is stretched such that disruptions become quickly apparent. 
So where does this lead Peabody? We are ideally positioned for this supercycle. Peabody benefits from rising volumes within a supportive price backdrop, a powerful earnings combination that should sustain our growth for years to come. In 2011, Peabody will use its position in the fastest-growing markets to target the following key areas: We will capture value from upward price, movements within our significant open position. We will advance expansion of six major Australian metallurgical and thermal export mines and work to recapture value loss from the recent flooding. We will advance emerging growth projects and commercial transactions in China, Mongolia, Indonesia and India. And we will continue to leverage Peabody's leadership in the three primary growth avenues for the U.S, the Powder River Basin; Illinois Basin; and U.S. exports. And we will maintain our intensity for excellence in our core areas of safety, operations, portfolio management, trading and brokerage and social responsibility. 
I want to thank all Peabody employees for their continued efforts. They are the key to our success. And we believe Peabody offers all of you a pure play investment for the global reach, access to the very best markets and growth rates well above our peers.
So with that overview, we'll now be happy to answer any questions you may have.

componenttext: Well, I think it's a good to know question, the comparison that needs to be made between 2008 and 2010 or '11 where we sit today in Australia. There's no question, Mike, although the flooding and the impacts in Australia  are much greater today than they were in the 2008, they're more widespread. They cover a larger area. If you remember back in 2008, there was a central core in Queensland along that Black Water line into Gladstone that was hardest hit. This year, there were impacts across the entire Queensland platform and right at the end of 2010, some impacts in New South Wales. When you look at 2010, you're probably 8 million to 10 million ton impact out of Australia. This year we're looking at 15 million to 20 million tons of total impact, so almost twice, plus you've got South Africa, you've got Colombia and Indonesia all having concurrent impacts. So when you look at the global perspective, this year's event is much more significant and in some cases, will take a longer period of time to recover depending on the region that we're talking about.

componenttext: Mike, this is Rick, I'll tackle that question. If we look at exports, I mean you saw an increase in exports last year, obviously, to a number about 80 million tons out of the United States. As we look forward and see what's happening around the globe, our estimate today, and I'd say it is 90-plus, with emphasis on the plus side, where we think 2011 is going to end up. We see prices that are high in Europe, that support more exports out of the Illinois Basin, out of the Colorado, out of the East. So really, every port is going to be more fully utilized as we go forward. So when we look at Peabody alone, I can tell in the fourth quarter as the markets begin to move, we locked in 7 million tons of export business in the fourth quarter of 2010.

componenttextpreview: Without going into specifics, mine by mine, on our force majeures, obviously, we've got a hell a lot of discussions with our customers. Let me just give a sense as to where we're at operationally today and what we see as some of the recovery times. If I j
componenttext: Without going into specifics, mine by mine, on our force majeures, obviously, we've got a hell a lot of discussions with our customers. Let me just give a sense as to where we're at operationally today and what we see as some of the recovery times. If I just start from the south, let's say that New South Wales is essentially back on track and operating normally from any impacts that they might have had in the fourth quarter. As we move up into Queensland, it's a couple of different stories. As I mentioned earlier, the most significant impacts and the most catastrophic impacts were along that Blackwater, Gladstone quarter, which we do not have any operations in that area. As you go to the Goonyella DBCT Port Corridor, which affects our northern Bowen Basin operations, and you look at our surface operations, our Burton operation, Eagle Field and Millennium, all had significant rainfall. Millennium is essentially up and running at capacity, although we've got some lower seams that we have still yet to pump the pits down to be able to access for blending purposes. Our Burton operation, we still have significant pumping to do. You might recall, we've got multiple pits at that operation. And we are beginning and we are producing out of some of those pits, but we don't have access to 100% of them yet. It'll take us a bit of time to pump those down. Eagle Field is essentially back up and running as an  adjunct to our North Goonyella operation. In terms of North Goonyella, we had some access issues, which will result fairly quickly. We also had a certain -- some geologic issues that we worked through at the end of the year. But it is essentially up and running at full production as we speak today. So as you move south to our Wilkie Creek operation, it's probably where we've had our biggest impact. We've just recently, within this week, been able to get full access to the site again and our back up limited production. And we'll be building that production base over the course of the next week. But longer term, the rail line from Wilkie Creek to port of Brisbane was washed out in the significant flooding that they had in Brisbane, which we're all aware of. And we're still talking to Queensland Rail as to what they think the repair estimates and time frame might be. But logically, that will probably be a month or two before we can see any clarity as to when that will be up and running. Hopefully, it won't not be longer than within the quarter.

componenttext: I guess my first question is kind of a follow-up from Mike's question, a little bit of philosophical in nature, but there's kind of a view out there that pricing from met will be impacted for the next two quarters because of the disruption and then settle back down to the 200 level by the fourth quarter and so forth. Have we opened up a gap that maybe we won't be able to close essentially and pricing will not necessarily fall down as far as some may think? I'm just kind of wondering what your view is on pricing kind of longer-term in terms of the path and so forth.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now
componenttext: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now at some point in time in the future, we're going to obviously see a recovery in terms of their production base. But at the meantime, demand continues to grow. So the gap that we've opened up, I think there's a significant portion of that gap that will permanent, albeit when things do normalize, we'll see some of the top end come down a bit. But we don't see that occurring in a very short period of time.

componenttext: Yes, we look at the first quarter, what I said in my remarks, is we expect higher average cost in the first quarter. You still got a knock on impact to the weather-related issues that we're going to have to deal with. At the same time, it remains to be seen ultimately what that's going to be. It's a little tough at this point to give you a specific guidance as to what it's going to be in the fourth quarter or in the first quarter. But when you look at the fourth quarter, we're going to the to have volume impacts. We need to work through the met and thermal mix. There will be a bit of upward pressure due to exchange rates even with our hedge position. We will see our -- have all an effective rate go up a bit. We'll see higher royalties on higher sales prices. So those are the couple drivers you have for the quarter.

componenttext: And just to make sure everyone's clear, the 15 million to 20 million ton impact that I talked about is industry-wide, obviously, not fully within our platform. So as Mike indicated, I mean, we'll have more clarity as we get through the quarter in terms of what the full impact is. I think the other question you asked is do we think that 15 million to 20 million is the end of it? It may not be in terms of -- and we don't have visibility into what all of the other producers and their various impacts are. As we talked about, co-shipping is still a risk that we have for the first quarter. So the 15 million to 20 million may actually increase somewhat as we go through the rest of the first quarter and the recovery effort is really kicking the place. So I think what everybody has remember is there's a significant amount of recovery across all of Queensland that has to take place, not just the coal sector. And so the resources will be strained as everybody tries to get back up and running and get the rail and the ports where they need to be.

componenttextpreview: Let me address that. Peabody continues with serious efforts to secure a long-term facility to ship what we've told you before, 20 million to 25 million tons of Powder River Basin coal to the Asian markets. We're evaluating the options with partners. And t
componenttext: Let me address that. Peabody continues with serious efforts to secure a long-term facility to ship what we've told you before, 20 million to 25 million tons of Powder River Basin coal to the Asian markets. We're evaluating the options with partners. And the reason we haven't said a lot about in our release is because we're confidentially agreements. But what I can tell is that our goal is to get a low-cost option that can be a game changer for the market. And when we look at the options, we want a deepwater facility, because to ship PRB coal, we believe you have to use capesize vessels. That improves your economics by $5 to $6 in metric ton over Panamax vessels that are being used in some of the other facilities that were available to us to look at. It has to have affordable rail opportunities and rail rates where -- and as we evaluate some of the further north opportunities such as Ridley, it's probably a $10 to $15 disadvantage to some of the other options that we look at. So we're trying to find the right option that has long-term competitive advantages, that can ship meaningful quantities of PRB coal. And it has a one-line haul as opposed to a two- or three-line rail haul to get to the port. So we hope to be able to give you information in the next quarter on this but it continues to progress very rapidly. A lot of work is going on, and we don't want to announce anything prematurely.

componenttext: Sure. Well, I'm not really up to speed on the specifics or what happened back in West Virginia with that one permit that you referenced. Suffice it to say that all of the permitting is under more scrutiny here in the U.S. What we have built into all of our planning processes is a longer time frame for permitting, which incorporates earlier acquisition of land resources so that the permits can be applied for at an earlier time frame, a longer window for both the state and federal permits to be received. We've been successful with that as evidenced by El Segundo, Bear Run, Wild Boar operations that we've started up all within the last couple of years. So it's something that everybody in the industry has to be cognizant of. I think we've done a great job of getting ahead of that curve and making sure that we've got our permits in place for our operations to start.

componenttext: Paul, this is Rick. Let me give you a little bit of background on the projects and there's a couple of other projects. We told you last quarter, we were working on these projects, and we'd hopefully have something to announce and we did. We're at the stage right now in both of these projects where we've signed Memorandums of Understanding. We're moving towards the signing of a joint venture agreement in mid-2011. And then, we'll work towards getting the permits for the coal reserves in 2011 as well. So at the same time we're finishing diligence and mine planning. But the expectation is, yes, these are significant projects. And in Peabody's case, we would expect to be 45% to 49% owners of coal mine and collecting revenues from, of course, that part of the business as well as participating at some level to be determined in the downstream part of the business as well. So in all likelihood, it won't be a consolidated revenue, it will be an equity method accounting in the future. It's probably at least three years in the future before we start having meaningful production of those operations, but we're very optimistic with these projects. And I think there's more to come as we head towards our goal that's pretty aggressive in Asia to expand our platform over there. So these are some good projects for us, and I think the endorsement by the Chinese government and U.S. government is very, very helpful as to get us to move forward and get those reserves secured.

componenttext: Well, I think first and foremost, what we're going to see is a good set of discussions in Washington around the regulatory environment and the impact that the regulatory environment and the potential new regulations that were being proposed will have on economic development, job growth, energy supply, as well as environmental progress. I think that all bodes well for what will be a more rational time frame as we go through the future in terms of what some of these new regulations might be. In terms of where we're at, in terms of permitting, current regulatory environment for new operations, I think those are moving along. I don't see significant changes there. I think it's more on the generation side, and I think there'll be a more fulsome discussion around the impacts of those at a time frame that allows continued electricity growth in this country as we move forward and not the jargoning effects of what we might have seen before.

componenttextpreview: Well, if you go back to our discussions last quarter and then if you go back to the comments earlier about the gap that we have today, I think it was always our view that the met coal supply was much tighter than where met coal demand was going to be. Tha
componenttext: Well, if you go back to our discussions last quarter and then if you go back to the comments earlier about the gap that we have today, I think it was always our view that the met coal supply was much tighter than where met coal demand was going to be. That was even before all of the Australian rains and all the other production issues across the globe. So that said, that we had the dynamics for upward pressure on price across the globe. So layer on top of that, the production has been lost, we don't have overcapacity in the met coal circuit. We've never thought that there as it existed, which says that for that gap to be closed, it might get tampered when we get back up to full production. But in our view, it's not going to get closed. We're going to have an even tighter supply situation going forward. You know 42%, 40-plus percent of all met coal supply is currently operating under force majeure which gives you kind of a sense as to the significance of the issues.

componenttext: Well, on the thermal sights, it's a different situation. Obviously we still see the thermal market tightening and it became particularly tight once met coal supply started to become short because you do have global, you've 20-plus million tons or more, 20 million to 30 million tons across over which is probably all moved over to the met side now. So we see with what's happened in Colombia, South Africa and Indonesia for the La Niña effects which is almost all predominantly thermal coal tightness in the thermal market as well. And significant run up in thermal pricing.

Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Thanks very much for taking part in the conference call for BTU. With us today are Chairman and CEO, Greg Boyce; Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Mike Crews; and President and Chief Commercial Officer, Rick Navarre.
Forward-looking statements should be considered along with the risk factors that we note at the end of our release, as well as the MD&A section of our filed documents. We also refer you to peabodyenergy.com for additional information.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we enter 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our mining operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14%, held the li
componenttext:
Thanks, Vic. I'm pleased to report that Peabody posted the second best year in our history and that we enter 2011 in our strongest financial position ever. To summarize, our mining operations delivered record results, we grew the top line 14%, held the line on cost and expanded margins across the platform. Our cash flow generation was substantial, and our balance sheet is stronger than ever. We raised our dividend, and we're executing on a number of growth projects all over the world. In short, Peabody has a long runway of growth and financial opportunities ahead. I'll begin with the review of our income statement and operational highlights.
Our 2010 sales volume totaled 246 million tons, slightly above last year as higher Western U.S. and Australian volumes more than offset lower Trading and Brokerage activity. Revenues reached a record $6.9 billion on a combination of improved realized prices and higher volumes in Australia and the Western U.S. Australia was a key driver with revenues $842 million above last year. Those higher prices, combined with lower U.S. costs, drove consolidated EBITDA to $1.82 billion, 41% above the prior year.
Moving on to taxes. Our effective tax rate, excluding currency remeasurement was 23% for the full year. Taxes for the fourth quarter were below previous quarters of 2010 due to lower-than-expected contributions from Australia, which have a higher effective tax rate. Going forward, we anticipate our full year effective tax rate will be up to 25% depending on the mix of earnings.
Income from continuing operations rose to $805.1 million. Excluding the impact of $48 million of non-cash currency remeasurement, our adjusted income from continuing operations totaled $853 million with adjusted diluted EPS of $3.05, both significantly above prior year levels.
Let me take you through the EBITDA components in more detail, beginning with Australia which more than doubled its contribution. Our volumes in Australia  reached 27 million tons, which was nearly 5 million tons higher than last year, reflecting both the investments we've made in the platform and the rising demand in the Pacific.
Breaking down Australia sales volumes, we sold 9.8 million tons of met coal in 2010 at an average price of $164 per metric ton, which was approximately 20% higher than last year. On the thermal side, we sold 11 million tons of seaborne thermal product throughout the year, our largest such volumes to date and at a higher average price of $78 per metric ton.
Let me take a moment to discuss the Australia rains that have been occurring most notably since December. For the industry, one of the hardest hit areas has been the mines and rail system serving the Gladstone port, which we don't ship through. For Peabody, we've been impacted by flooding to varying degrees at our service mines and have also seen reduced rail and port performance.
The combination of lower-than-expected fourth quarter volumes, along with repair recovery expenses, reduced EBITDA approximately $85 million or $0.22 per share after tax. The first quarter will also be impacted by lower volumes as we ramp back up to normal levels.
In 2010, our full year cost in Australia averaged $58 per ton in line with our expectations despite the rain effects. All told, our Australia gross margin rose to 38% for the year versus 26% in 2009.
Turning now to the U.S. Our operations ran very well, and related EBITDA rose 14% to $1.1 billion. In the Midwest, our margins per ton increased 22% to nearly $11 per ton as higher contracted prices more than offset a modest increase in cost from slightly lower volumes. And in the West, our margins increased 11% on higher average revenues and costs that were more than 2% below 2009 levels.
All in, our consolidated Mining Operations turned in record results. We also generated $101 million of EBITDA from our Trading and Brokerage and Resource Management businesses. You'll know our fourth quarter Trading results were lower than average largely due to three factors. First, we had lower international brokerage earnings relative to higher 2009 performance. We also had some shipment deferrals due to the Australia weather, several of which had since shipped or are expected to ship this quarter. 
And finally, the freight position that supports our future expert volumes had unfavorable mark-to-market movements. Weather depressed the freight markets, causing them to decline in the fourth quarter versus an increase last year. Like the deferrals, these are temporary and at the latest, will reverse when the shipments occur.
Going forward, we continue to target quarterly EBITDA from this segment at the two-year quarterly average of approximately $30 million. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Our strong performance resulted in cash flows from operations of $1.1 billion, which drove our cash balance to $1.3 billion. Our rise in cash flow allowed us to increase our dividend by more than 20% even as we fund a number of growth projects.
The capital program for 2011 is rising to accommodate our organic growth projects. Of this year's $900 million to $950 million of planned spending, $500 million to $550 million is earmarked for growth in extension projects in Australia and the U.S. 2011 sustaining capital is estimated to average approximately $1.80 per produced ton on continued modernization of our equipment fleet.
Before I close, I'd like to cover our outlook. For the first quarter, we're expecting lower sales volumes and higher average costs due to the rains in Australia. We also have a longwall move planned for Colorado and one in Australia. As a result, first quarter EBITDA is targeted in the range of $325 million to $425 million with adjusted earnings per share of $0.45 to $0.65.
For the full year, our U.S. volumes are targeted to be 195 million to 205 million tons, with stable average margins across the platform, leading to expected U.S. EBITDA within 5% of 2010. Australia sales are targeted to be 28 million to 30 million tons compared with 27 million tons in 2010. And with Trading and Brokerage, our total company 2011 sales are likely to be in the 245 million to 265 million-ton range. Given the rapid market developments and their potential for meaningful impact, we look forward to providing you outlook updates throughout the year.
And so with that review, a very strong 2010 results and our outlook, I'll now turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the are
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 2010 was a year of significant accomplishments for Peabody across the board. Absent the December weather impacts, 2010 EBITDA would have been our best year ever. And as it is, we set new company records in the areas such as global safety and revenues and had major increases in our EBITDA, operating profit and income. We started up the Bear Run Mine in the Midwest and shipped our first coal through the NCIG terminal in Newcastle. We expanded El Segundo in New Mexico and sold record volumes from our premium PRB North Antelope Rochelle Mine, and we moved forward our project pipeline in Australia and various JVs in China, Mongolia and Indonesia.
We began 2011 solidly in the first phase of a long-term coal supercycle. And Peabody has growth projects advancing in Australia, Asia and in the U.S. I'd like to review the key markets for our products as well as our key focus areas for 2011. 
This year, we see a continuation of the two-speed global economic engine with China, India and emerging Asia growing at 8% to 10%, and Europe and the U.S. still in lower gear. In the Pacific seaborne market, coal demand grew nearly 20% in 2010 to a record 700 million tons. China continued as the world's fastest-growing coal importer and shattered its prior year net import record with 147 million tons. India continue to expand the coal imports, and Japan and Korea also bounced back from earlier recession.
This year, we expect further robust growth in global seaborne coal demand, which may exceed 1 billion metric tons for the first time ever, look for China and India to again lead the growth, and at the same time coal supplies are being challenged by events in most major exporting nations. 
The Southern Hemisphere is home to more than 3/4 of the world's seaborne coal supplies. La Nina has brought heavy rains to Australia, Indonesia, South Africa and South America, as well exports have been hampered in the Eastern U.S. and Western Canada. So rising demand and strained supplies are translating into sharp price increases. Just since October, the spot met coal price is up well over 50%, and the Newcastle thermal has risen more than 35%. 
This bodes extremely well as we approach upcoming settlements for quarterly met in annual thermal contracts. And our leverage to these markets is outstanding. Essentially all of Peabody's met coal beyond this quarter is open to pricing and half of our thermal export coal is available to price for 2011, with 85% open for 2012.
Now Mike reviewed the effects of the Australia flooding on our results. I'd like to the give you a brief update where we stand today. Our Cleveland mines continue to work through force majeures with customers and recover from the storms. Today, the major questions are what will the normal rainy season, which we’re just beginning, bring to us? Whether our coast shippers will have coal available when we have coal product ready to ship? And for our Wilkie Creek operation, when will the rail line to the Brisbane Port be restored? 
We receive multiple reports each day from our Australia team, which has been working tirelessly through personal and professional challenges. But their goal is to minimize the impacts of flooding and to recover as quickly as possible. A case in point, we just sold a spot Panamax of semi-hard coking coal to a major customer for prices that are significantly above those settled for the first quarter.
So as we quickly work through these short-term weather-related issues, we're keenly focused on capturing the significant upside potential resulting from the 7 million to 8 million tons of metallurgical coal and the 6 million to 7 million tons of thermal coal that we have yet to price for 2011.
Now let's look at the U.S. markets. Last year, a low natural gas price still wasn't enough to derail a 5.5% increase in coal-fueled generation. Coal regained market share in 2010 and powered nearly 2/3 of incremental power outlet. Exports increased, led by met coal in the East and PRB in the West. And I'd note that U.S. coal demand has largely tracked industrial output, which while declining 9% in 2009, bounced back 6% in 2010. We see muted improvement in 2011 with manufacturing growth, natural gas prices and export volumes holding the keys to any further increases.
On the supply side, we expect continued market share gains from the Illinois Basin and Powder River Basin. And we continue to shape our contract book to the match the curve of the U.S. rebound, with 2012 and beyond continuing to look much brighter.
Now embedded in these near-term market movements are elements of much longer trends. I've noted that I believe we're in the early stages of a long-term supercycle for coal. We see evidence of these around us today. Coal has been the world's fastest-growing fuel, and EIA [Energy Information Administration]
Projects that growth in coal generation will be more than double that of any other fuel through 2020. And by 2020, global generation capacity in steel production are both expected to grow some 50%. China's electricity and industrial production will again grow at low-teen rates, and China's new power plants and steel mills will require several hundred million tons of added coal each year. 
India is rapidly raising coal imports and developed economies are starting to see growth in their manufacturing base. So what's important to investors goes beyond whether met coal is $375 per ton. The key is that global demand for coal is strongly and steadily rising, and supply is stretched such that disruptions become quickly apparent. 
So where does this lead Peabody? We are ideally positioned for this supercycle. Peabody benefits from rising volumes within a supportive price backdrop, a powerful earnings combination that should sustain our growth for years to come. In 2011, Peabody will use its position in the fastest-growing markets to target the following key areas: We will capture value from upward price movements within our significant open position. We will advance expansion of six major Australian metallurgical and thermal export mines and work to recapture value loss from the recent flooding. We will advance emerging growth projects and commercial transactions in China, Mongolia, Indonesia and India. And we will continue to leverage Peabody's leadership in the three primary growth avenues for the U.S, the Powder River Basin; Illinois Basin; and U.S. exports. And we will maintain our intensity for excellence in our core areas of safety, operations, portfolio management, trading and brokerage and social responsibility. 
I want to thank all Peabody employees for their continued efforts. They are the key to our success. And we believe Peabody offers all of you a pure play investment for the global reach, access to the very best markets and growth rates well above our peers.
So with that overview, we'll now be happy to answer any questions you may have.

componenttext: Well, I think it's a good to know question, the comparison that needs to be made between 2008 and 2010 or '11 where we sit today in Australia. There's no question, Mike, that the flooding and the impacts in Australia are much greater today than they were in the 2008, they're more widespread. They cover a larger area. If you remember back in 2008, there was a central core in Queensland along that Black Water line into Gladstone that was hardest hit. This year, there were impacts across the entire Queensland platform and right at the end of 2010, some impacts in New South Wales. When you look at 2010, you're probably 8 million to 10 million ton impact out of Australia. This year we're looking at 15 million to 20 million tons of total impact, so almost twice, plus you've got South Africa, you've got Colombia and Indonesia all having concurrent impacts. So when you look at the global perspective, this year's event is much more significant and in some cases, will take a longer period of time to recover depending on the region that we're talking about.

componenttext: Mike, this is Rick, I'll tackle that question. If we look at exports, I mean you saw an increase in exports last year, obviously, to a number about 80 million tons out of the United States. As we look forward and see what's happening around the globe, our estimate today, and I'd say it is 90-plus, with emphasis on the plus side, where we think 2011 is going to end up. We see prices that are high in Europe, that support more exports out of the Illinois Basin, out of the Colorado, out of the East. We see what's happening in the West Coast, there's opportunities that move it. And we're also moving a lot more coal out of the Gulf. So really, every port is going to be more fully utilized as we go forward. So when we look at Peabody alone, I can tell you in the fourth quarter as the markets began to move, we locked in 7 million tons of export business in the fourth quarter of 2010.

componenttextpreview: Without going into specifics, mine by mine, on our force majeures, obviously, we've got a have a lot of discussions with our customers. Let me just give a sense as to where we're at operationally today and what we see as some of the recovery times. If I j
componenttext: Without going into specifics, mine by mine, on our force majeures, obviously, we've got a have a lot of discussions with our customers. Let me just give a sense as to where we're at operationally today and what we see as some of the recovery times. If I just start from the south, let's say that New South Wales is essentially back on track and operating normally from any impacts that they might have had in the fourth quarter. As we move up into Queensland, it's a couple of different stories. As I mentioned earlier, the most significant impacts and the most catastrophic impacts were along that Blackwater, Gladstone quarter, which we do not have any operations in that area. As you go to the Goonyella DBCT Port Corridor, which affects our northern Bowen Basin operations, and you look at our surface operations, our Burton operation, Eaglefield and Millennium, all had significant rainfall. Millennium is essentially up and running at capacity, although we've got some lower seams that we have still yet to pump the pits down to be able to access for blending purposes. Our Burton operation, we still have significant pumping to do. You might recall, we've got multiple pits at that operation. And we are beginning and we are producing out of some of those pits, but we don't have access to 100% of them yet. It'll take us a bit of time to pump those down. Eaglefield is essentially back up and running as an adjunct to our North Goonyella operation. In terms of North Goonyella, we had some access issues, which will result fairly quickly. We also had a certain -- some geologic issues that we worked through at the end of the year. But it is essentially up and running at full production as we speak today. So as you move south to our Wilkie Creek operation, it's probably where we've had our biggest impact. We've just recently, within this week, been able to get full access to the site again and are back up limited production. And we'll be building that production base over the course of the next week. But longer term, the rail line from Wilkie Creek to port of Brisbane was washed out in the significant flooding that they had in Brisbane, which we're all aware of. And we're still talking to Queensland Rail as to what they think the repair estimates and time frame might be. But logically, that will probably be a month or two before we can see any clarity as to when that will be up and running. Hopefully, it won't be longer than within the quarter.

componenttext: I guess my first question is kind of a follow-up from Mike's question, a little bit of philosophical in nature, but there's kind of a view out there that pricing from met will be impacted for the next two quarters because of the disruption and then settle back down to the 200 level by the fourth quarter and so forth. Sort of given your comments about 1 billion-ton-plus seaborne-traded market growth in all the areas there. Have we opened up a gap that maybe we won't be able to close essentially and pricing will not necessarily fall down as far as some may think? I'm just kind of wondering what your view is on pricing kind of longer-term in terms of the path and so forth.

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now
componenttext: Well, I think our view is that we have opened up a significant gap between supply and demand, with demand continuing to be extremely strong. And to have a view that pricing is going to recover within a short period of time is not a view that we have. Now at some point in time in the future, we're going to obviously see a recovery in terms of their production base. But at the meantime, demand continues to grow. So the gap that we've opened up, I think there's a significant portion of that gap that will permanent, albeit when things do normalize, we'll see some of the top end come down a bit. But we don't see that occurring in a very short period of time.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we look at the first quarter, what I said in my remarks, is we expect higher average cost in the first quarter. You still got a knock on impact to the weather-related issues that we're going to have to deal with. At the same time, it remains to be se
componenttext: Yes, we look at the first quarter, what I said in my remarks, is we expect higher average cost in the first quarter. You still got a knock on impact to the weather-related issues that we're going to have to deal with. At the same time, it remains to be seen ultimately what that's going to be. It's a little tough at this point to give you a specific guidance as to what it's going to be in the fourth quarter or in the first quarter. But when you look at the fourth quarter, we're going to continue to have volume impacts. We need to work through the met and thermal mix. There will be a bit of upward pressure due to exchange rates even with our hedge position. We will see our -- have all an effective rate go up a bit. We'll see higher royalties on higher sales prices. So those are the couple drivers you have for the quarter.

componenttext: And just to make sure everyone's clear, the 15 million to 20 million ton impact that I talked about is industry-wide, obviously, not fully within our platform. So as Mike indicated, I mean, we'll have more clarity as we get through the quarter in terms of what the full impact is. I think the other question you asked is do we think that 15 million to 20 million is the end of it? It may not be in terms of -- and we don't have visibility into what all of the other producers and their various impacts are. As we talked about, co-shipping is still a risk that we have for the first quarter. So the 15 million to 20 million may actually increase somewhat as we go through the rest of the first quarter and the recovery efforts really kick into place. So I think what everybody has remember is there's a significant amount of recovery across all of Queensland that has to take place, not just the coal sector. And so the resources will be strained as everybody tries to get back up and running and get the rail and the ports where they need to be.

I know Arch [Arch Coal, Inc.] and a few others have made a few announcements, but I was wondering if you felt that there would be any likelihood that you can get that announcement in that 20 million to 30 million ton range in the near term and whether that would have more of an impact in 2011 and 2012, or would that be more of a long-dated agreement?

headline: Peabody Energy Corp., 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 25, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me address that. Peabody continues with serious efforts to secure a long-term facility to ship what we've told you before, 20 million to 25 million tons of Powder River Basin coal to the Asian markets. We're evaluating the options with partners. And t
componenttext: Let me address that. Peabody continues with serious efforts to secure a long-term facility to ship what we've told you before, 20 million to 25 million tons of Powder River Basin coal to the Asian markets. We're evaluating the options with partners. And the reason we haven't said a lot about in our release is because we're confidentially agreements. But what I can tell is that our goal is to get a low-cost option that can be a game changer for the market. And when we look at the options, we want a deepwater facility, because to ship PRB coal, we believe you have to use capesize vessels. That improves your economics by $5 to $6 in metric ton over Panamax vessels that are being used in some of the other facilities that were available to us to look at. It has to have affordable rail opportunities and rail rates where -- and as we evaluate some of the further north opportunities such as Ridley, it's probably a $10 to $15 disadvantage to some of the other options that we look at. So we're trying to find the right option that has long-term competitive advantages, that can ship meaningful quantities of PRB coal. And it has a one-line haul as opposed to a two- or three-line rail haul to get to the port. So we hope to be able to give you information in the next quarter on this but it continues to progress very rapidly. A lot of work is going on, and we don't want to announce anything prematurely.

componenttext: Sure. Well, I'm not really up to speed on the specifics or what happened back in West Virginia with that one permit that you referenced. Suffice it to say that all of the permitting is under more scrutiny here in the U.S. What we have built into all of our planning processes is a longer time frame for permitting, which incorporates earlier acquisition of land resources so that the permits can be applied for at an earlier time frame, a longer window for both the state and federal permits to be received. We've been successful with that as evidenced by El Segundo, Bear Run, Wild Boar operations that we've started up all within the last couple of years. So it's something that everybody in the industry has to be cognizant of. I think we've done a great job of getting ahead of that curve and making sure that we've got our permits in place for our operations to start.

componenttext: Paul, this is Rick. Let me give you a little bit of background on the projects and there's a couple of other projects. We told you last quarter, we were working on these projects, and we'd hopefully have something to announce and we did. We're at the stage right now in both of these projects where we've signed Memorandums of Understanding. We're moving towards the signing of a joint venture agreement in mid-2011. And then, we'll work towards getting the permits for the coal reserves in 2011 as well. So at the same time we're finishing diligence and mine planning. But the expectation is, yes, these are significant projects. And in Peabody's case, we would expect to be 45% to 49% owners of coal mine and collecting revenues from, of course, that part of the business as well as participating at some level to be determined in the downstream part of the business as well. So in all likelihood, it won't be a consolidated revenue, it will be an equity method accounting in the future. It's probably at least three years in the future before we start having meaningful production of those operations, but we're very optimistic with these projects. And I think there's more to come as we head towards our goal that's pretty aggressive in Asia to expand our platform over there. So these are some good projects for us, and I think the endorsement by the Chinese government and U.S. government is very, very helpful as to get us to move forward and get those reserves secured.
